												Ring Runner ReviewI bought the game on sale for $8, which works out to be pennies an hour worth of game play.  It’s hard to tell how many hours I have put into the game because the last Steam client update wiped my hours played, but before the wipe it said about 118, and since then I have put on 54 according to the current count.  I spent about 8-10 hours perfecting three ship builds, which involved mostly sitting in the menus with a calculator doing math, add in another few hours reading mission info, setting up random ships and looking at equipment.  I figure actual playtime through the main campaign took about 40-50 hours; more then what was listed in the product description.  This is probably because on several missions it would tell me things like quickly leave the battlefield or I needed to lose the fight so it can show me what happens when I die;  instead I decided to stick around and fight for long periods.  Couple this with flying around exploring environments [when possible] and sitting back listening to an amazing sound track.  Figure 30-50 hours for the main campaign which will also vary based on your difficulty setting.The game was an impulse buy, one that was triggered by watching the trailer and hearing the amazing music tracks, watching the trippy explosions, and all out chaos of the ship battles.  I am not a fan of top down arcade style space shooters and prefer 4x stuff like the X Series or overly complicated, hard to learn and brutally unforgiving games like Eve Online.  With that said, Ring Runner had far more depth then any arcade style shooter I have tried. For a game made by a small handful of people, I was shocked at its production value.  You will have a hard time telling it’s made by a small team of people.  It’s too bad the main stream [un]professional donkie-hole full time game reviewers seem to ignore indie games, because Ring Runner has not gotten the publicity it deserves.  I can only assume because they are a small team that does not have the capital needed to bribe the broken, deceiving, lying, incompetent main stream game review websites that only exist to sell ads and ruin gaming by coddling to big corporations that are increasingly taking a crap on a plate and charging you for the “privilege” of having it shoved down your throat.  I can assure you that spending $10 on this game, like it or hate it, will not leave you with the taste of feces in your mouth that comes from spending $60 a game on the typical horse $hit you are probably used to by now coming out of corporate America.  It’s worth buying Ring Runner just on principle IMO, but as a bonus you are getting an amazing game which should lead to many hours of fun game play.The best way to describe the game is to think of it as a fantasy RPG with your typical fighter, Mage, Rogue, etc class system but with the ships you fly determining which “class” you are playing.  Just like in your typical RPG there are different item slots that hold different equipment which do different things.  Pretty standard for an RPG, not so standard for a space shooter.  The combination took me [pleasantly] by surprise when I finally figured out the game mechanics.  The dev is active on Steam and responds quickly to requests, questions, and concerns.  You can tell the game is a labor of love and a lot of time has been put into getting things right.  I have only had a small handful of black screen crashes, though they did require a forced PC reboot, overall the game is very stable, in fact looking at a lot of big title releases I would say it’s far more stable than Battlefield 4, X Rebirth, Rome 2, etc.  It’s hard to believe considering those other games have millions in production costs and far more people working on fixing problems.  The following are some negatives though I do not expect these to get fixed because IMO I have already gotten far more then I paid for and I know the dev is working on another project.  The game is already “complete” so the following is just for reference when making choices on future games.  There are some minor annoyances like AI ships picking up already scarce “plex” [money] in scenarios like death match, which will probably anger some people when trying to farm.  I noticed several AI ships flying around not shooting; rather just intentionally heading to the plex drops and picking them up before I could get over and do it myself.  This does not happen in missions, but when you are at endgame and trying to play with different builds which all cost a lot of plex, it makes things very obnoxious.  I understand AI characters picking up power-ups and would expect nothing less, but plex should not be something they can take as the AI has no need for in game money.  Post Game expect grinding for plex; a lot of grinding.  If you did the math from the first paragraph of this review you are probably wondering where the other 50+ hours went; the answer is playing [mostly] one mission over and over grinding for plex so I could buy different ships/equipment to try different builds.  The dev stated they were working on a minor fix, but it’s not hard to figure out why there are not a lot of Steam workshop builds online as its pointless to post a ship unless its set up properly which takes a lot of in game money.My last gripe is that 95% of the equipment can only be used once per build.  This makes sense with some heavy hitting guns but not other very weak ones.  It makes it very hard to create a balanced build with anything other than just a few setups.  My guess is this is also why there are very few builds up on Steam’s workshop.  Sure, you can pile 8+ different crappy weapons into a ship, each with a different cool down timer, different amounts of heat or energy, each doing a different effect, but at the end of the day you will be doing nothing but button mashing for less DPS, more heat, and more energy use then you would get out of one decent weapon.  Oh, and good luck timing those 8+ weapons to actually hit your target as the game is very fast paced with flying feeling like you are on a rubber band shooting through space.  I am not saying it’s not fun to play with different builds, but at the end of the day you will probably just stick to one or two main weapons to max out DPS with the least Heat/Energy consumption.  A lot of things may look great on paper with a calculator, but in practice you can easily break the game with a few well thought-out builds.Lastly, equipment descriptions are all over the place with some giving damage per second and others giving damage per shot, and still yet others give no description of damage leaving it to trial and error.I know I ended this on a slightly sour note, but the game is anything but sour.  It took me over a hundred hours to break things, which was a lot of fun in the process.  That works out to less than ten cents an hour which is the cheapest you will probably ever pay for a game.  I don’t expect the devs to do anything else with it as again it’s a complete game.  If you are on the fence about buying it I highly recommend spending the $10 and having some fun.  The story is not bad [better than most high budget games today] and the dialog will defiantly will put a smile on your face.  By the end I was sitting on the edge of my seat swearing at the “bad guys” and loving how I was just wrecking them for the crap they pulled earlier.  It’s not often anymore a game will pull that emotion out of you with its story.  Again, fun times.Thank you VERY much for an amazing game and I will be keeping an eye out on Kickstarter for your next release. Score: 8/10

												Wow, this is a really underrated little gem.  I grabbed it as part of a Humble Bundle, put it in my library, and promptly forgot about it.  I loaded it up not too long ago and was pleasantly surprised!  Ring Runners is a top-down 2D space shooter with deep ship customization elements and a lengthy story mode.   I was fondly reminded of the good 'ol days of 2D space shooters like Escape Velocity.  Between missions, you can use credits to purchase new hulls and new gear to fit in them.   There are various different hull types, each focused on maximizing some attribute or another.  Some hull types are fast and lightly armored, others are behemoths loaded for bear.  The campaign is a lot of fun, and it takes a long time to fully play out.  It's silly at times, and serious at other times.  My only complaint is that it takes a while to open up all the options and let you really fully enjoy all the possibilities.  My only other complaint is that ship customization can be a bit of a chore.  There's a lot of clicking on stuff to figure out what it does, and even with descriptions sometimes it's hard to figure out whether or not something would actually be useful to you.  The game's systems are complex enough that there's a lot of non-obvious mechanics at work.

												Ring Runner is a top down shooter ARPG with a rather large campaign considering the genre it's in. My older brother recommended this game to me and gifted it to me on steam and it was a blast to play. I was interested in the story and I enjoyed the sense of humor in the dialogue. The combat system this game has responsive, tight controls with (Depends on the class and how you fit your engines)  bit of a twist thanks to the newtonian physics. Every key is fully rebindable in the options and you can manually bind your ships abilities in the ship creator you unlock later to fit any control scheme you desire. My only real complaint is that the game takes a bit to hook you in, as the best part is the all of the ways you can fit your ships to just about any play style and control scheme you can think of. At least try to make it to the Dvorak Galaxy! More indepth review here: http://extra-credits.net/forum/viewtopic.php?f=9&t=7167&p=137145

												I would recommend this at the advertised price 9.99 but you might wait for a sale.I love the concept of it being an RPG, but it's not.  The tutorial is kind of rpgish but very structured--few choices in customization and ship choice so they can introduce you to all the ships.The problem is that afterwards all the level 1-3 ships, most hulls and a bunch of level 5 prebuilts are all open.At that point it's not an RPG, it's a combat/shooter with a decent choice of ships and weapons.I restarted hoping for an "RPG" mode where you start with a single, tiny fighter hull and work your way up but no--you skip the tutoral and they just open up everything including 1-2 of each highest level prebuilt hull.I realize many people don't like RPGs and so they just want to get to the highest level with every option open and fight, but if that's the case kindly don't advertise it as an RPG.  For isntance, Diablo 3 is this way--levels 1-70 are paretty much a tutorial and then you start playing after level 70.  Stop calling these things RPGs, they are fighting games with extended tutorials--that's it.Still, not at all bad for the price.  Even has a MOBA map that's pretty cool.If an RPG mode was introduced to (optionally) replace the extended tutorial with slower advancement and less initially unlocked I'd be really happy with this game.
